bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 4, 1900

div1.p: Reed gives an assessment of the criticism directed at the experimental project. He believes that it is unfounded.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 4, 1900
div1.opener:
A Kiss
for Mr
D. Johnson.
Don't forget
to acknowledge
check which
I sent in my
Monday's letter.
Columbia Barracks,
Quemados, Cuba,
Dec. 4th 1900.
My precious wifie;
div1.p:
Your dear
letter written on Thanks-
giving-Day came yesterday --
the first quick trip for
any of your letters, since
my return to Cuba- The mail,
also, brought a long, sweet
letter from precious stu-
dent- I'll have to answer
hers to-night- Just to think
that this is dear Darboy's
23rd birth-day! Well, to be
sure, lovie, dear, between
boys of twenty-three and
the arrival of gout, you
and I must be getting along
pretty well towards a ripe,
old age! How old is that
precious fat daughter?
You musn't worry, however,
about the size of that toe-
joint, as it will slowly
subside and resume its nor-
mal size- You have begun to
get out-doors earlier
than I thought you would.
Hurrah! for the lady who
can go to the market and
to Matinees! You will slowly
get back to your pace, and
such eating and drinking as
my sweet Miss Farmer-lady
will do in order to make
up for lost time; well I
& Miss Bird-tamer will have
to take a back-seat! wait
until Sis Mott's Eczema and
Sis Meadow's gout have taken
a more favorable turn, and
I shall have to plant two
mint-beds! He! He! Ha!! Ha!!
Dear Me! what “miss Know-
-all” lady have you been
talking to, to work my sweet
wifie into such a nervous
state about our work
here? Let them talk all
they please, my sweetheart-
We know what we are
doing- The world is filled
with people (asses) who
don't want to know any
thing about the propagation
of various diseases, inclu-
ding yellow fever! They
had rather have thousands
sicken & die of it, so they
are not affected by it!
The Marine Hospital Service
would gladly choke off
our experimentation, for it
may prove that all their
disinfection has been
for naught- We are fol-
lowing along careful lines
and believe that we are
doing just what is right
& absolutely necessary in
order to ascertain the
causation of yellow fever-
We are not doing what
any reasonable person
should criticize us for-
We are not compelling
any one to subject himself
to any danger without he
really expresses a desire
in writing to do so-
My advice to my sweet
wifie is to cease talking
with any one about it
and, if possible, stop think-
ing about it- Nobody
has suffered any harm
from what we have done
so far, and it may be
that we will obtain no
results, but, of course,
it is much too early to
to draw conclusions yet.
Just let the matter drop,
dearest, out of your thoughts,
& remember that no one ever tried
to do any good for the world
& the people in it, who
escaped the harshest
criticism from his fellow-
man! It has always
been thus, & doubtless
always will be. Cheer up!
you sweet joy & stop both-
ering your darling head
& heart about these things.
Tuesday night. I stopped here,
this morning, and wrote a short
letter of congratulations on his
birth-day to Lt. Reed, of
Cienfuegos, and, also, a short
letter to that sweetest of
daughters, Miss B. Reed,
formerly of Georgetown-
Since morning, the wind has
suddenly changed from South
to North and has been blowing
quite hard, which, I dare say,
means more cold weather
in the states- Don't let that pre-
cious toe get chilled, lovie,
dear, or old Mr “Go-out” might
grab hold of it and throw
you into bed again! and then
you couldn't “go out”! see?
How is the atmosphere of
12 18 now during the cold snaps?
Any warmer than it used
to be? I do so much hope that
the winter won't be a cold
one -- and that my sweet oom-
sey can get a chance to go
out and take exercise in
the bright sunlight- Goodnight,
you sweet joys- Boo! Boo!
wednesday morning -- 5th- Hoop-
la! how are my precious
pigs, this morning? The wind
is blowing like sixty and
although the temperature is
72°, it feels decidedly chilly.
I have come very near over-
sleeping, this morning, as
it is now within a few min-
utes of 7 o'clock, & I think
I hear the rattle of the mail-
wagon, but as my envel-
ope is already addressed
(I do that the night before)
it only takes a second to close
my letter- Don't let Jack-Frost
catch my sweet girls! Turn
on the steam, when it gets cold!
Love to Lucy, Mrs. D. & Miss Mason
Take care of your precious selves.
Love & kisses & kisses & love
for my pretty pretty girls-
